member.name: T:Nucleus.Actions.ActionInputAttribute
member.summary: Attributes of an action input parameter property. Used to specify information about the input and how it should be obtained/used.

member.name: P:Nucleus.Actions.ActionInputAttribute.Manual
member.summary: If true, the input will be prompted for as an input when this action is run as a manual command. Default = true

member.name: P:Nucleus.Actions.ActionInputAttribute.Parametric
member.summary: If true, the input will be made available as an input when this action is used as a parametric component. Default = true

member.name: P:Nucleus.Actions.ActionInputAttribute.Required
member.summary: If true, this input *must* be set to a non-null value or the command will not be executed. Default = true

member.name: P:Nucleus.Actions.ActionInputAttribute.Persistant
member.summary: If true, the value specified for this input will be re-used as the default value the next time the command is run. Default = false

member.name: P:Nucleus.Actions.ActionInputAttribute.Import
member.summary: If true (and the data is of an importable type) the data is to be loaded from an external file rather than selected from the current document An import dialog of the appropriate type will be displayed Default = false

member.name: P:Nucleus.Actions.ActionInputAttribute.Dialog
member.summary: If true, this input will be set via an auto-generated options dialog Default = false

member.name: P:Nucleus.Actions.ActionInputAttribute.OneByOne
member.summary: Only applies to collection types when being wrapped inside a paramatric component. If true (default) objects in this collection will be processed one at a time and the action executed once for each item individually.

member.name: P:Nucleus.Actions.ActionInputAttribute.SuggestionsPath
member.summary: The path of the property on the action which will supply a list of suggested values for the user to choose from. Used to enable text input with selection from a set of options.

member.summary: Constructor

member.name: T:Nucleus.Actions.ActionParameterAttribute
member.summary: Base class for Action Parameter attributes. Used to annotate action input and output properties in order to define more information about how they should be used.

member.name: P:Nucleus.Actions.ActionParameterAttribute.Order
member.summary: Weighting value for the display order. Parameters will be sorted by this value. Lower values will be displayed first.

member.name: P:Nucleus.Actions.ActionParameterAttribute.ShortName
member.summary: The abbreviated version of this property name to be displayed in limited-space situations such as grasshopper inputs and outputs. If not explicitly set, the short name will usually be generated automatically from the property name itself.

member.name: P:Nucleus.Actions.ActionParameterAttribute.Description
member.summary: The description of this parameter. This may be displayed as a tooltip or a prompt. In the latter case, this string may be prefixed with 'Enter ' - therefore do not capitalise the first letter of this description unless it should always be capitalised (i.e. it is a noun). In cases where there is no prefix, the first letter will be automatically capitalised.

member.name: P:Nucleus.Actions.ActionParameterAttribute.CapitalisedDescription
member.summary: A version of the Description property with the first character capitalised

member.name: T:Nucleus.Actions.ExecutionInfo
member.summary: A class which contains information about the context in which an action has been executed. This is used during object history storage to determine the object's creation circumstances and can be used to update that object in future.

member.name: F:Nucleus.Actions.ExecutionInfo._ExecutionID
member.summary: Private backing field for ExecutionID property

member.name: P:Nucleus.Actions.ExecutionInfo.ExecutionID
member.summary: The unique identifier of this particular execution. This will be different each time and can be used to tell execution runs apart.

member.name: F:Nucleus.Actions.ExecutionInfo._SourceReference
member.summary: Private backing field for SourceReference property

member.name: P:Nucleus.Actions.ExecutionInfo.SourceReference
member.summary: The reference string used to identify the source of execution of an action, used to update previously created output instead of generating it afresh when used as part of a parametric process. For example, this may be the GUID of the calling grasshopper component. Defaults to null when the source is not parametric (i.e. when called manually).

member.name: F:Nucleus.Actions.ExecutionInfo._Iteration
member.summary: Private backing field for Iteration property

member.name: P:Nucleus.Actions.ExecutionInfo.Iteration
member.summary: The iteration number of this execution. This will increment when the same source calls this action multiple times during the same update cycle - for example when a list of inputs is plugged into a Grasshopper component.

member.name: F:Nucleus.Actions.ExecutionInfo._HistoryItemCount
member.summary: Private backing field for HistoryItemCount property

member.name: P:Nucleus.Actions.ExecutionInfo.HistoryItemCount
member.summary: The number of history-tracked items that have been created or updated during this execution. This will be incremented automatically by the source history manager

member.summary: Default constructor for manual execution

member.summary: Constructor from parametric source

member.name: T:Nucleus.Actions.IAction
member.summary: An interface which must be implemented by any class which represents an action. You can implement this interface entirely yourself, but probably it is better simply to inherit from an appropriate base class (ActionBase, DocumentActionBase etc.), which will provide a lot of the basic functionality for you.

member.name: M:Nucleus.Actions.IAction.Execute(Nucleus.Actions.ExecutionInfo)
member.summary: Execute this action. Input parameters will be consumed and output parameters will be populated.
member.param: A set of data communicating the parametric context of execution. Used to update existing outputs from the same parametric source instead of generating new ones. Will be null if the source is not part of a parametric process.
member.returns: Should return true if the action is successfully completed, false otherwise

member.name: M:Nucleus.Actions.IAction.PreExecutionOperations(Nucleus.Actions.ExecutionInfo)
member.summary: A function which will be called before the action is executed in normal execution mode.
member.returns: True if execution can be allowed to proceed

member.name: M:Nucleus.Actions.IAction.PostExecutionOperations(Nucleus.Actions.ExecutionInfo)
member.summary: A function which will be called after the action has been executed in normal execution mode. Override to define specific behaviours - typically to consume the outputs of the execution.

member.name: M:Nucleus.Actions.IAction.FinalOperations(Nucleus.Actions.ExecutionInfo)
member.summary: A function which will be called on the last action to be executed in a sequence, after any PostExecutionOperations have been performed. For example, in a Grasshopper component dealing with multiple inputs, this will only be called once all inputs have been dealt with. Use this to define any tidying up operations that should be performed after the final iteration.

member.name: M:Nucleus.Actions.IAction.InputParameters
member.summary: Return a list of the PropertyInfo objects for all input parameters of this action.

member.name: M:Nucleus.Actions.IAction.OutputParameters
member.summary: Return a list of the PropertyInfo objects for all output parameters of this action.

member.summary: Use the current input manager to prompt the user for all necessary inputs to this action
member.returns: True if all inputs successful, false if user cancels

member.name: T:Nucleus.Base.IFastDuplicatable
member.summary: Interface for objects which implement a 'FastDuplicate()' method to create duplicates of objects. This duplication must be manually implemented and so there is a lot more implementation work involved than with the fully automatic IDuplicatable interface but the resulting duplication may be significantly more efficient as the use of reflection can be avoided.

member.name: M:Nucleus.Base.IFastDuplicatable.FastDuplicate_Internal
member.summary: Method used by the FastDuplicate() extension method. Implement this explicitly and manually construct a copy of the original type.

member.name: T:Nucleus.Base.IFastDuplicatableExtensions
member.summary: Extension methods for the IFastDuplicateble

member.name: M:Nucleus.Base.IFastDuplicatableExtensions.FastDuplicate``1(``0)
member.summary: Produce a duplicate of this object. This is an alternative to the more general Duplicate() method. Unlike Duplicate() this does not (always) use reflection and must be manually implemented, meaning that it may be significantly faster in execution but that not all properties are guaranteed to be fully duplicated (though key ones should be). This is typically used to optimise performance-critical code where the normal duplication framework would be too expensive.

member.name: T:Nucleus.Base.CollectionCopyAttribute
member.summary: Attribute applied to collection types and fields to determine the correct procedure for dealing with them when automatically copying their values and their contents to another object. By default, fields are 'shallow-copied' - i.e. values and references are copied. It is only necessary to apply this attribute to fields where this behaviour should be changed. Attributes applied to types define the default behaviour of that type, but field-level attributes will override this where present.

member.name: P:Nucleus.Base.CollectionCopyAttribute.ItemsBehaviour
member.summary: The behaviour of the items contained within the annotated field during a copy operation. By default, properties have their values 'shallow-copied', but may instead be prevented from being copied or be duplicated instead, provided the property type is duplicatable.

member.name: T:Nucleus.Base.IUniqueWithModifiableGUID
member.summary: Interface for unique objects which allow you to modify their GUID. This is generally a very bad idea and is intended for use only when deserialising uniques or when wanting to produce an *exact* copy between two separate models. The main purpose of this interface is to make setting the GUID difficult to do without due consideration - implement this interface explicitly to prevent its members showing up in intellisense.

member.name: T:Nucleus.Base.CopyAttribute
member.summary: Attribute applied to types and fields to determine the correct procedure for dealing with them when automatically copying their values to another object. By default, fields are 'shallow-copied' - i.e. values and references are copied. It is only necessary to apply this attribute to fields where this behaviour should be changed. Attributes applied to types define the defauly behaviour of that type, but field-level attributes will override this where present.

member.name: P:Nucleus.Base.CopyAttribute.Behaviour
member.summary: The behaviour of the annotated field during a copy operation. By default, properties have their values 'shallow-copied', but may instead be prevented from being copied or be duplicated instead, provided the property type is duplicatable.

member.name: M:Nucleus.Base.CopyAttribute.#ctor(Nucleus.Base.CopyBehaviour)
member.summary: Constructor. Initialise this attribute with the specified copying behaviour.
member.param: The copying behaviour of this field.

member.name: T:Nucleus.Base.CopyBehaviour
member.summary: Enum used to describe the behaviour of a field during a data copying operation

member.name: F:Nucleus.Base.CopyBehaviour.COPY
member.summary: Copy the value or reference assigned to the field - i.e. create a 'shallow' copy. This is the default behaviour, you do not need to specify this value.

member.name: F:Nucleus.Base.CopyBehaviour.DO_NOT_COPY
member.summary: The field should not be copied at all - the original value of the field should not be overwritten. Use when a field should survive a copy operation without being modified - for example the GUID of the object.

member.name: F:Nucleus.Base.CopyBehaviour.DUPLICATE
member.summary: Duplicate the object assigned to this field, creating a 'deep copy'. The object type of this field *must* itself implement the IDuplicatable interface in order for this value to be valid.

member.name: F:Nucleus.Base.CopyBehaviour.MAP
member.summary: Map the reference assigned to this field to the duplication of that object created during this same copy operation. If no such object has been included in this duplication thus far, do not copy anything. Use this when you have a back-reference to a parent object and want that reference to kept to the *new* parent when copied, unless the child object is being copied on its own and will not *have* a parent.

member.name: F:Nucleus.Base.CopyBehaviour.MAP_OR_COPY
member.summary: Map the reference assigned to this field to the duplication of that object created during this same copy operation. If no such object has been included in this duplication thus far, copy the reference itself.

member.name: F:Nucleus.Base.CopyBehaviour.MAP_OR_DUPLICATE
member.summary: Map the reference assigned to this field to the duplication of that object created during this same copy operation. If no such object has been included in this duplication thus far, create that duplicate. The object type of this field *must* itself implement the IDuplicatable interface in order for this behaviour to be valid.

member.name: T:Nucleus.Base.IDuplicatable
member.summary: Interface for objects which can be duplicated. Objects implementing this interface automatically gain a 'Duplicate()' extension method which uses reflection to procedurally create a new object and populate its properties to create a duplicate of the original. Duplicating produces a shallow clone with the exception of property values which are expected to be unique per instance of the object, which will themselves be duplicated. This is determined by tagging those properties with the CopyBehaviour attribute.

member.name: T:Nucleus.Base.IDuplicatableExtensions
member.summary: Extension methods for the IDuplicatable interface

member.name: M:Nucleus.Base.IDuplicatableExtensions.Duplicate``1(``0,Nucleus.Base.CopyBehaviour)
member.summary: Produce a duplicated copy of this object. Family references will be copied, save for those which are intended to be unique to this object, which will themselves be duplicated. This method uses reflection to walk through the full property tree of the object and copy property values automatically depending on the CopyBehaviour they are tagged with. This is convenient and comprehensive, but can be very slow - be wary of overusing it in performance-critical scenarios.
member.param: The duplication behaviour of items contained within this object, if this object is a collection
member.returns: A duplicated copy of this object

member.name: M:Nucleus.Base.IDuplicatableExtensions.Duplicate``1(``0,System.Collections.Generic.Dictionary{System.Object,System.Object}@,Nucleus.Base.CopyBehaviour)
member.summary: Produce a duplicated copy of this object. Family references will be copied, save for those which are intended to be unique to this object, which will themselves be duplicated.
member.param: The map of original objects to duplicated objects.
member.returns: A duplicated copy of this object

member.name: M:Nucleus.Base.IDuplicatableExtensions.CopyPropertiesFrom(System.Object,System.Object)
member.summary: Populate the properties of this object by copying them from equivalent public fields on another object. The properties to be copied must share names and types in order to be successfully transferred.

member.name: M:Nucleus.Base.IDuplicatableExtensions.CopyFieldsFrom(System.Object,System.Object)
member.summary: Popualate the fields of this object by copying them from equivelent fields on another object. The fields to be copied must share names and types in order to be successfully transferred.
member.param: The object to copy fields from.

member.name: M:Nucleus.Base.IDuplicatableExtensions.CopyFieldsFrom(System.Object,System.Object,System.Collections.Generic.Dictionary{System.Object,System.Object}@)
member.summary: Populate the fields of this object by copying them from equivalent fields on another object. The fields to be copied must share names and types in order to be successfully transferred. The CopyAttribute will be used to determine the correct behaviour when copying fields accross - first on the field itself and then, if not set, on the type of the field. If neither of these is specified the default is to do a 'shallow' or reference-copy on all objects except for collection type, where the default is to not copy any fields *unless* they are specifically annotated.
member.param: The object to copy fields from.
A map of original objects to their copies. Used when duplicating multiple objects at once to create links between them of the same relative relationships.

member.name: M:Nucleus.Base.IDuplicatableExtensions.ValueToAssign(System.Object,Nucleus.Base.CopyBehaviour@,Nucleus.Base.CopyBehaviour,System.Collections.Generic.Dictionary{System.Object,System.Object}@)
member.summary: Convert the value extracted from the source object into an equivalent value suitable to be assigned to the target property, based on the copying behaviour assigned

member.name: M:Nucleus.Base.NotifyPropertyChangedBase.ChangeProperty``1(``0@,``0,System.String,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Helper method to modify the backing field of a property and perform associated activities on a single line. In addition to updating the specified backing field a PropertyChanged event will be raised using the extended argument set that includes both previous and new values of the property. This can be used as the basis for undo operations.
member.typeparam: The type of the property
member.param: The backing field to be changed
The new value to be assigned
The name of the property. If not specified the CallerMemberName will be used.
If false (default), a property changed notification will not be raised unless the old and new values of the property are not equal. If true, it will be raised regardless.

member.summary: Static extension methods on any object type

member.name: M:Nucleus.Extensions.ObjectExtensions.SetByPath(System.Object,System.String,System.Object,Nucleus.Conversion.IStringConversionContext)
member.summary: Set the value of a property on this object at the specified path
member.param: The path, consisting of property names and sub-property names separated by '.' characters. For example: 'PropertyName.SubPropertyName.SubSubPropertyName' etc. Parameterless methods may also be invoked by adding '()', i.e.: 'PropertyName.SubMethodName().SubSubPropertyName'. Methods and properties on the optional context object may also be invoked in the same way, via a '*' redirection. For example: '*.MethodName()'. When switching to the context object the SetSourceObject method on it will be called and the current object or property value passed in. This allows for complex operations to be performed in order to return a value provided that functionality is implemented in a suitable context object provided.
The value to be assigned to the property
The (optional) string conversion context object. If supplies this allows the '*' symbol to be used within property paths in order to access properties and functions supplied on the context object.

member.name: M:Nucleus.Extensions.ObjectExtensions.GenerateBindingChain(System.Object,System.String)
member.summary: Generate a binding chain for the specified path on this object. A binding chain is a list of all objects in the chain which implement the INotifyPropertyChanged interface accompanied by the name of the property on that object which, when changed, will require the bindings of objects further down the chain to be refreshed.

member.name: M:Nucleus.Extensions.ObjectExtensions.GetFromPath(System.Object,System.String,Nucleus.Conversion.IStringConversionContext)
member.summary: Get the value of a property on this object at the specified path
member.param: The path, consisting of property names and sub-property names separated by '.' characters. For example: 'PropertyName.SubPropertyName.SubSubPropertyName' etc. Parameterless methods may also be invoked by adding '()', i.e.: 'PropertyName.SubMethodName().SubSubPropertyName'. Methods and properties on the optional context object may also be invoked in the same way, via a '*' redirection. For example: '*.MethodName()'. When switching to the context object the SetSourceObject method on it will be called and the current object or property value passed in. This allows for complex operations to be performed in order to return a value provided that functionality is implemented in a suitable context object provided.
The (optional) string conversion context object. If supplies this allows the '*' symbol to be used within property paths in order to access properties and functions supplied on the context object.

member.name: M:Nucleus.Extensions.ObjectExtensions.ToString(System.Object,System.String,System.Char,System.Char,System.String,System.String,Nucleus.Conversion.IStringConversionContext)
member.summary: Convert this object to a string in the specified format.
member.param: The format to be used to construct the text string. This should take the form of a string interspersed with property paths surrounded by open and close tag characters, the values of which will be inserted into the text. For example "The value of the subproperty is: {PropertyName.SubPropertyName}"
The opening tag for specifying property paths. Default is '{'.
The closing tag for specifying property paths. Default is '}'.
The (optional) string conversion context object. If supplies this allows the '*' symbol to be used within property paths in order to access properties and functions supplied on the context object.

member.name: T:Nucleus.Geometry.IWidePath
member.summary: Interface for geometric objects which are linear and follow a spine curve but that have sufficient width on plan for the left and right edges to be represented by separate curves. For example; roads, building wings, beam representations in GAs, etc. This interface provides attached extension functions to allow the generation of geometry representing the boundaries of a network of paths.

member.name: P:Nucleus.Geometry.IWidePath.Spine
member.summary: The spine curve from which the outer curves are to be derived

member.summary: The left edge curve

member.name: P:Nucleus.Geometry.IWidePath.RightEdge
member.summary: The right edge curve

member.summary: The offset distance of the left edge from the spine

member.name: P:Nucleus.Geometry.IWidePath.RightOffset
member.summary: The offset distance of the right edge from the spine

member.name: P:Nucleus.Geometry.IWidePath.LeftEndPinch
member.summary: The 'pinch' distance applied to the left-hand edge ends in order to induce curvature in the left-hand edge curve

member.name: P:Nucleus.Geometry.IWidePath.RightEndPinch
member.summary: The 'pinch' distance applied to the right-hand edge ends in order to induce curvature in the right-hand edge curve

member.summary: The curve capping the left side of the starting end of the path. Will usually be null.

member.summary: The curve capping the right side of the starting end of the path. Will usually be null.

member.summary: Replace the initially generated path edges with arcs with offset ends to induce curvature in the outer edges.

member.param: A normalised parameter along the path (where 0 = Start, 1 = End)
A list of normalised parameters across the path (where 0 = Left, 1 = Right)

member.param: A list of normalised parameters along the path (where 0 = Start, 1 = End)
A list of normalised parameters across the path (where 0 = Left, 1 = Right)

member.summary: Find the intersection point, if one exists, for two infinite lines on the XY plane. For 3D, use the Axis class and ClosestPoint function instead. This version also provides the parameters on the two lines - i.e. the multiplication factor necessary to apply to the line direction vector to get to the intersection point from the line origin.
member.param: The origin point of the first line
The direction of the first line
The origin point of the second line
The direction of the second line
The parameter on the first line
The parameter on the second line
member.returns: The XY intersection point, if one exists. Else (the lines are null or parallel) Vector.Unset

member.summary: Find the intersection point, if one exists, for two lines on the XY plane. By default, the lines will be treated as extending to infinity, but may optionally be bounded to not return intersections outside the extents of the lines themselves.
member.param: The first line
The second line
If true, intersections outside the bounds of the line segments specified will be ignored.

The parameter-space range on each line where intersections are valid

member.summary: Find the intersection points, if any exist, for an infinite line and a circle on the XY plane, given as an array of doubles representing multiplication factors which should be applied to the line direction vector. There may be one, two or zero intersection points.

The direction vector of the line
The centre point of the circle
The radius of the circle
member.returns: An array of doubles representing the line parameters of the intersection points

member.name: M:Nucleus.Geometry.Intersect.LineCircleXY(Nucleus.Geometry.Line,Nucleus.Geometry.Circle,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Find the intersection points, if any exist, for a line and a circle on the XY plane. Note that for the purposes of calculation both are assumed to lie on the XY plane even if they do not. By default, the line is assumed to be infinite, however the calculation may optionally be bounded to exclude intersections outside of the bounds of the specified line segment
member.param: The line.
The circle. This should lie on the XY plane for the calculation to be accurate.

member.name: M:Nucleus.Geometry.Intersect.LineArcXY(Nucleus.Geometry.Vector,Nucleus.Geometry.Vector,Nucleus.Geometry.Arc,System.Boolean)

The vector from the start of the line to its end
The arc
Optional. If true, intersections which lie outside of the extents of the line will be ignored.

member.summary: Find the intersection points, if any exist, for a line and an arc on the XY plane. By default, the line is assumed to be infinite, however the calculation may optionally be bounded to exclude intersections beyond the ends of the specified line segment
member.param: The start point of the line
The vector from the start of the line to its end
The arc
The range on the line, as a proportion of the line length, where intersections will be valid. 0 will represent the start of the line and 1 its end.

member.name: M:Nucleus.Geometry.Intersect.PolygonOverlapXY``1(System.Collections.Generic.IList{Nucleus.Geometry.Vertex},System.Collections.Generic.IList{Nucleus.Geometry.Vertex},System.Collections.Generic.IList{Nucleus.Geometry.Vertex})
member.summary: Find the overlapping region(s) between two polygons, represented as sets of vertices. Uses an algorithm similar to that presented in Efficient Clipping of Arbitrary Polygons by Gunter Greiner and Kai Hormann: http://davis.wpi.edu/~matt/courses/clipping/. The returned polygons will be composed of the vertices of the previous polygons plus additional ones at the intersection points. Note that you may need to create copies of these if the pre-existing vertices already form part of a separate geometry object.
member.param: The set of vertices representing the first polygon
The set of vertices representing the second polygon
Optional. The collection of vertices, to which any vertices created during this process should be added

member.summary: Calculate the equivalent number of meters per degree of latitude at the specified reference latitude, taking account of the elliptical nature of the Earth. Should be accurate to within 1m per degree anywhere on the Earth. Based on this article: https://knowledge.safe.com/articles/725/calculating-accurate-length-in-meters-for-lat-long.html
member.param: The reference latitude at which the conversion is to take place

member.name: M:Nucleus.Geometry.Mesh.DelaunayTriangulationXY(Nucleus.Geometry.VertexCollection,Nucleus.Geometry.MeshFaceCollection,Nucleus.Geometry.BoundingBox,System.Boolean,Nucleus.Geometry.VertexCollection)
member.summary: Generate a set of mesh faces that represent a delaunay triangulation in the XY plane of the specified set of vertices. Based on the algorithm described here: http://paulbourke.net/papers/triangulate/
member.param: The vertices to mesh between
Optional. The face collection to which to add the triangles. If null or ommitted, a new MeshFaceCollection will be created.

The bounding box that contains the triangulation. Should encompass all vertices and, for later voronoi generation, any bounding geometry. If null, the bounding box of the vertices themselves will be used.

Clean up construction Super Triangle. If true, any remaining fragments of the initial generating supertriangle will be removed from the output face list. Set this to false if planning on using this mesh for subsequent voronoi generation so that the edge cells can be extended.

Optional. If input and non-null, this collection will be populated with the exterior vertices - those connected to the original supertriangle. If 'clean' is false, this will instead return the supertriangle vertices.

member.name: M:Nucleus.Geometry.Mesh.VoronoiFromDelaunay(Nucleus.Geometry.VertexCollection,Nucleus.Geometry.MeshFaceCollection,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Convert a set of mesh faces generated via delaunay triangulation into its dual - the voronoi diagram of the vertices.

member.summary: Sort the vertices of this face counter-clockwise around the specified point in plan (i.e. in the XY plane). This will essentially align this face 'upwards'. Note that this will only work in the case of convex polygons where the ordering of vertices is not important.

member.name: M:Nucleus.Geometry.MeshFace.CalculateArea
member.summary: Calculate the surface area of this face using the half cross-product formula. For quad and n-gon faces, the face will be treated as a triangle fan around the first vertex (i.e. it is assumed to be non-reentrant).

member.summary: Calculate the surface area (and centroid) of this surface

member.name: M:Nucleus.Geometry.Surface.CalculateArea
member.summary: Calculate the surface area of this surface

members.member:
Evaluate the local coordinate system of this surface. By convention, the z-axis of the local coordinate system will point normal to the surafce and the x-axis will be orientated as closely as possible to global X, unless the x-axis lies within a certain angular limit of z, in which case the global Y axis will be used instead.
The index of the face on which to evaluate the local coordinate system A normalised parameter defining the first coordinate of a point on this surface. Note that parameter-space is not necessarily uniform and does not equate to a normalised length. 0 = span start, 1 = span end. /// A normalised parameter defining the first coordinate of a point on this surface. Note that parameter-space is not necessarily uniform and does not equate to a normalised length. 0 = span start, 1 = span end. The orientation angle. The rotation of the X and Y axes of the coordinate system around the Z axis, relative to default reference orientation.

member.name: M:Nucleus.Geometry.Surface.LocalCoordinateSystem(Nucleus.Geometry.Angle)
member.summary: Evaluate the local coordinate system of this surface. By convention, the z-axis of the local coordinate system will point normal to the surafce and the x-axis will be orientated as closely as possible to global X, unless the x-axis lies within a certain angular limit of z, in which case the global Y axis will be used instead.
member.param: The orientation angle. The rotation of the X and Y axes of the coordinate system around the Z axis, relative to default reference orientation.

member.name: M:Nucleus.Geometry.Arc.CalculateLength
member.summary: Calculate and return the length of this arc

member.name: M:Nucleus.Geometry.Arc.PointAt(System.Double)
member.summary: Evaluate a point on this curve defined by a parameter t
member.param: A normalised parameter defining a point along this curve. Note that parameter-space is not necessarily uniform and does not equate to a normalised length. 0 = curve start, 1 = curve end. For open curves, parameters outside the range 0-1 will be invalid. For closed curves, parameters outside this range will 'wrap'.
member.returns: The vector coordinates describing a point on the curve at the specified parameter, if the curve definition and parameter are valid. Else, an unset vector.
member.remarks: The base implementation treats the curve as being defined as a polyline, with straight lines between vertices.

member.name: M:Nucleus.Geometry.Arc.PointAt(System.Int32,System.Double)
member.summary: Evaluate a point defined by a parameter within a specified span.
member.param: The index of the span. Valid range 0 to SegmentCount - 1
A normalised parameter defining a point along this span of this curve. Note that parameter-space is not necessarily uniform and does not equate to a normalised length. 0 = span start, 1 = span end.
member.returns: The vector coordinates describing a point on the curve span at the specified parameter, if the curve definition and parameter are valid. Else, null.
member.remarks: The base implementation treats the curve as being defined as a polyline, with straight lines between vertices.

member.name: M:Nucleus.Geometry.Arc.ParameterAt(System.Double)
member.summary: Get the curve parameter at the specified length along this curve. If the returned parameter falls outside the range 0-1, the specified length does not fall within the domain of the curve.
member.param: The distance along the curve from the start of the curve to the point in question
member.returns: A curve parameter

member.name: M:Nucleus.Geometry.Arc.TangentAt(System.Double)
member.summary: Evaluate the tangent unit vector of a point on this curve defined by a parameter t
member.param: A normalised parameter defining a point along this curve. Note that parameter-space is not necessarily uniform and does not equate to a normalised length. 0 = curve start, 1 = curve end. For open curves, parameters outside the range 0-1 will be invalid. For closed curves, parameters outside this range will 'wrap'.
member.returns: The tangent unit vector of the curve at the specified parameter
member.remarks: The base implementation treats the curve as being defined as a polyline, with straight lines between vertices.

member.name: M:Nucleus.Geometry.Arc.IsClockwiseIn(Nucleus.Geometry.CylindricalCoordinateSystem)
member.summary: Is this arc clockwise with respect to the specified coordinate system? The coordinate system specified should have its origin at the centre of this arc's circle.

member.name: M:Nucleus.Geometry.Arc.IsClockwiseXY
member.summary: Is this curve clockwise in the XY plane?

member.name: M:Nucleus.Geometry.Arc.SectorIxx(System.Double,System.Double)
member.summary: The area moment of inertia of a filled circular sector or angle theta in radians and radius r with respect to an axis through the centroid of the circle Used in the calculation of enclosed area second moments of area
member.param: The sector angle in radians in the range 0 to 2*PI

member.name: M:Nucleus.Geometry.Arc.Offset(System.Double,System.Boolean,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Offset this curve on the XY plane.
member.param: The offset distance. Positive numbers will result in the offset curve being to the right-hand side, looking along the curve. Negative numbers to the left.

member.name: M:Nucleus.Geometry.Arc.OffsetInwards(System.Double@,System.Boolean,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Offset this curve on the XY plane, automatically determining (where possible) the direction of offset which will result in the curve being offset within itself. Note that it will not be possible to accurately predict this for all curves.
member.param: The offset distance. Positive numbers will result in the offset curve being to the right-hand side, looking along the curve. Negative numbers to the left. This will be automatically inverted (in-place) if the curve is anticlockwise so that positive numbers entered will result in an offset inwards and negative numbers outwards.

member.name: M:Nucleus.Geometry.Arc.Offset(System.Collections.Generic.IList{System.Double},System.Boolean,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Offset this curve on the XY plane by varying distances for each span.
member.param: The offset distance. Positive numbers will result in the offset curve being to the right-hand side, looking along the curve. Negative numbers to the left.
If true (default) collapsed segments will be removed.

member.name: M:Nucleus.Geometry.Axis.IntersectPlane(Nucleus.Geometry.Plane)
member.summary: Find the position along this axis, as a multiplication factor of the direction vector where this axis crosses a plane.
member.param: The plane to find the intersection point with.
member.returns: The factor that it is necessary to multiply the direction factor by and add to the origin in order to obtain the intersection point, if an intersection point exists. Use PointAt to resolve this to a vector if required. If the Axis is parallel to the plane and there is no intersection then double.NaN will be returned instead.

member.name: M:Nucleus.Geometry.Axis.Closest(Nucleus.Geometry.Vector)
member.summary: Find the position along this axis that is closest to the specified point. Expressed as a multiplication factor of the direction vector from the origin.
member.param: The test point.
member.returns: The parameter, t, on this axis that describes the point on this axis closest to the test point. Expressed as a multiplication factor of the direction vector from the origin. Use PointAt to evaluate this as a vector if required.

member.name: M:Nucleus.Geometry.Axis.ClosestParameter(Nucleus.Geometry.Axis,System.Double@)
member.summary: Find the position along this axis that is closest to the specified other axis. Expressed as a multiplication factor of the direction vector from the origin.
member.param: OUTPUT. The parameter on the other axis.
member.returns: The parameter on this axis describing the closest point to the other axis. Use PointAt to resolve this into a vector if required.
member.remarks: Algorithm based on http://geomalgorithms.com/a07-_distance.html

member.name: T:Nucleus.Geometry.Curve
member.summary: Base class for curves. Curves are 1-Dimensional geometries defined by a set of ordered vertices.
member.remarks: This class implements a default set of interrogation methods, which will treat this curve as a polyline of straight segments between vertices. While most curve functionality is implemented on the relevent subclass, any new curve types should also take care to also add support to the relevent functions within the Intersect helper class and any relevant conversion classes in dependent libraries.

member.name: P:Nucleus.Geometry.Curve.Closed
member.summary: Whether this curve is closed. If true, the end of the curve is treated as being the same as the start point. Default (for most curve types) is false.

member.name: P:Nucleus.Geometry.Curve.Domain
member.summary: Get the parameter-space domain of this curve

member.name: P:Nucleus.Geometry.Curve.Start
member.summary: Get the vertex at the start of the curve (if there is one)

member.name: P:Nucleus.Geometry.Curve.End
member.summary: Get the vertex at the end of the curve (if there is one)

member.name: P:Nucleus.Geometry.Curve.StartPoint
member.summary: Get the start point of this curve

member.name: P:Nucleus.Geometry.Curve.EndPoint
member.summary: Get the end point of this curve

member.name: P:Nucleus.Geometry.Curve.Length
member.summary: Get the length of this curve

member.name: M:Nucleus.Geometry.Curve.PointAt(System.Double)
member.summary: Evaluate a point on this curve defined by a parameter t
member.param: A normalised parameter defining a point along this curve. Note that parameter-space is not necessarily uniform and does not equate to a normalised length. 0 = curve start, 1 = curve end. For open curves, parameters outside the range 0-1 will be invalid. For closed curves, parameters outside this range will 'wrap'.
member.returns: The vector coordinates describing a point on the curve at the specified parameter, if the curve definition and parameter are valid. Else, an unset vector.
member.remarks: The base implementation treats the curve as being defined as a polyline, with straight lines between vertices.

member.name: M:Nucleus.Geometry.Curve.PointsAt(System.Collections.Generic.IList{System.Double})
member.summary: Evaluate a set of points along this curve defined by a set of parameters
member.param: A set of normalised parameters defining points along this curve. Note that parameter-space is not necessarily uniform and does not equate to a normalised length. 0 = curve start, 1 = curve end. For open curves, parameters outside the range 0-1 will be invalid. For closed curves, parameters outside this range will 'wrap'.
member.returns: The vector coordinates describing a point on the curve at the specified parameter, if the curve definition and parameter are valid. Else, an unset vector.

member.name: M:Nucleus.Geometry.Curve.PointAt(System.Int32,System.Double)
member.summary: Evaluate a point defined by a parameter within a specified span.
member.param: The index of the span. Valid range 0 to SegmentCount - 1
A normalised parameter defining a point along this span of this curve. Note that parameter-space is not necessarily uniform and does not equate to a normalised length. 0 = span start, 1 = span end.
member.returns: The vector coordinates describing a point on the curve span at the specified parameter, if the curve definition and parameter are valid. Else, null.
member.remarks: The base implementation treats the curve as being defined as a polyline, with straight lines between vertices.

member.name: M:Nucleus.Geometry.Curve.PointAtLength(System.Double,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Evaluate a point on this curve a specified distance from the start or end.
member.param: The length along the curve
If true, the length will be measured from the end of the curve. If false (default) it will be measured from the start.

member.name: M:Nucleus.Geometry.Curve.ParameterAt(Nucleus.Geometry.Vertex)
member.summary: Get the curve parameter at the specified vertex
member.param: The vertex. Must be a defining vertex of this curve.
member.returns: A curve parameter

member.name: M:Nucleus.Geometry.Curve.ParameterAtVertexIndex(System.Int32)
member.summary: Get the curve parameter at the vertex at the specified index

member.name: M:Nucleus.Geometry.Curve.ParameterAt(System.Double)
member.summary: Get the curve parameter at the specified length along this curve. If the returned parameter falls outside the range 0-1, the specified length does not fall within the domain of the curve.
member.param: The distance along the curve from the start of the curve to the point in question
member.returns: A curve parameter

member.name: M:Nucleus.Geometry.Curve.ParametersAtSpacing(System.Double,System.Double,System.Int32)
member.summary: Returns a set of parameters evenly spaced along the curve with a specified spacing
member.param: The distance between points
The distance of the first point from the start of the curve.
Optional. The maximum number of parameters to be produced. If set to 0 or below, the number of possible returned parameters is unlimited.

member.name: M:Nucleus.Geometry.Curve.ParametersAtDivisions(System.Int32,System.Double)
member.summary: Returns a set of parameters at equidistant points along this curve produced by dividing the curve into equal length segments.
member.param: The number of equal segments to divide the curve into.
The position of the point within each segment, as a proportion of the segment length. Between 0-1, where for e.g. 0 is at the start of each segment, 0.5 is in the middle and so on.

member.name: M:Nucleus.Geometry.Curve.LengthAt(System.Double)
member.summary: Calculate the length along the curve of the specified parameter

member.name: M:Nucleus.Geometry.Curve.TangentAt(System.Double)
member.summary: Evaluate the tangent unit vector of a point on this curve defined by a parameter t
member.param: A normalised parameter defining a point along this curve. Note that parameter-space is not necessarily uniform and does not equate to a normalised length. 0 = curve start, 1 = curve end. For open curves, parameters outside the range 0-1 will be invalid. For closed curves, parameters outside this range will 'wrap'.
member.returns: The tangent unit vector of the curve at the specified parameter
member.remarks: The base implementation treats the curve as being defined as a polyline, with straight lines between vertices.

member.name: M:Nucleus.Geometry.Curve.TangentAt(System.Int32,System.Double)
member.summary: Evaluate the tangent unit vector of a point defined by a parameter within a specified span.
member.param: The index of the span. Valid range 0 to SegmentCount - 1
A normalised parameter defining a point along this span of this curve. Note that parameter-space is not necessarily uniform and does not equate to a normalised length. 0 = span start, 1 = span end.
member.returns: The unit vector describing the tangent of a point on the curve span at the specified parameter, if the curve definition and parameter are valid. Else, null.
member.remarks: The base implementation treats the curve as being defined as a polyline, with straight lines between vertices.

member.name: M:Nucleus.Geometry.Curve.CheckSegmentTangents(Nucleus.Geometry.Curve)
member.summary: Compare this curve to another by span tangencies. Returns true only if the two curves have the same number of spans and the curve tangencies at the mid-point of each span are facing within 90 degrees of one another.

member.name: M:Nucleus.Geometry.Curve.LocalCoordinateSystem(System.Double,Nucleus.Geometry.Angle)
member.summary: Evaluate the local coordinate system at a position along this curve. By convention, the x-axis of the local coordinate system will point along the curve and the z-axis will be orientated as closely as possible to global Z, unless the x-axis lies within a certain angular limit of z, in which case the global X axis will be used instead.
member.param: A normalised parameter defining a point along this curve. Note that parameter-space is not necessarily uniform and does not equate to a normalised length. 0 = span start, 1 = span end.
The orientation angle. The rotation of the Y and Z axes of the coordinate system around the X axis, relative to default reference orientation.

member.name: M:Nucleus.Geometry.Curve.LocalCoordinateSystem(System.Double,Nucleus.Geometry.Angle,Nucleus.Geometry.Angle)
member.summary: Evaluate the local coordinate system at a position along this curve. By convention, the x-axis of the local coordinate system will point along the curve and the z-axis will be orientated as closely as possible to global Z, unless the x-axis lies within a certain angular limit of z, in which case the global X axis will be used instead.
member.param: A normalised parameter defining a point along this curve. Note that parameter-space is not necessarily uniform and does not equate to a normalised length. 0 = span start, 1 = span end.
The orientation angle. The rotation of the Y and Z axes of the coordinate system around the X axis, relative to default reference orientation.
The angular limit within which if the local X and global Z approach each other, local Z will be aligned towards global X rather than global Z. By default, this is 1 degree.

member.name: M:Nucleus.Geometry.Curve.LocalCoordinateSystem(System.Int32,System.Double,Nucleus.Geometry.Angle)
member.summary: Evaluate the local coordinate system at a position along this curve. member.param: A normalised parameter defining a point along this span of this curve. Note that parameter-space is not necessarily uniform and does not equate to a normalised length. 0 = span start, 1 = span end.
The orientation angle. The rotation of the Y and Z axes of the coordinate system around the X axis, relative to default reference orientation.

member.name: M:Nucleus.Geometry.Curve.CalculateEnclosedArea(Nucleus.Geometry.Plane)

member.name: M:Nucleus.Geometry.Curve.CalculateEnclosedArea(Nucleus.Geometry.Vector@,Nucleus.Geometry.Plane)
member.summary: Calculate the area enclosed by this curve, were the start and end points to be joined by a straight line segment. A plane may optionally be specified, otherwise by default the projected area on the XY plane will be used.
member.param: Output. The centroid of the enclosed area.
The plane to use to calculate the area. If not specified, the XY plane will be used.
member.returns: The signed area enclosed by this curve on the specified plane, as a double.

member.name: M:Nucleus.Geometry.Curve.CalculateEnclosedArea(Nucleus.Geometry.Vector@,Nucleus.Geometry.CurveCollection,Nucleus.Geometry.Plane)
member.summary: Calculate the combined area enclosed by this curve, were the start and end points to be joined by a straight line segment, but excluding areas bounded by a specified set of void curves. member.param: Output. The centroid of the enclosed area.

A collection of curves which represent the boundaries of void spaces within the perimeter of this curve. Voids must be co-planar with and wholly within the bounds of this curve for the calculation to be accurate. May be null.
The plane to use to calculate the area. If not specified, the XY plane will be used.
member.returns: The signed area enclosed by this curve on the specified plane, as a double.

member.name: M:Nucleus.Geometry.Curve.CalculateEnclosedIxx(Nucleus.Geometry.Plane)
member.summary: Calculate the second moment of area enclosed by this curve on a the XY plane about the X-axis, were the start and end points joined by a straight line segment. A coordinate system may be specified, otherwise by default the global XY plane and X-axis will be used.
member.param: The coordinate system in which the second moment of area is to be calculated. The second moment of area will be calculated on the XY plane and about the X-axis of this system.
member.returns: The signed second moment of area enclosed by this curve, as a double.

member.name: M:Nucleus.Geometry.Curve.CalculateEnclosedIxx(Nucleus.Geometry.CurveCollection,Nucleus.Geometry.Plane)
member.summary: Calculate the second moment of area enclosed by this curve on a the XY plane about the X-axis, were the start and end points joined by a straight line segment, excluding the void regions specififed as boundaries. A coordinate system may be specified, otherwise by default the global XY plane and X-axis will be used.
member.param: A collection of curves which represent the boundaries of void spaces within the perimeter of this curve. Voids must be co-planar with and wholly within the bounds of this curve for the calculation to be accurate. May be null.
The coordinate system in which the second moment of area is to be calculated. The second moment of area will be calculated on the XY plane and about the X-axis of this system.
member.returns: The signed second moment of area enclosed by this curve, as a double.

member.name: M:Nucleus.Geometry.Curve.CalculateEnclosedIyy(Nucleus.Geometry.CurveCollection)
member.summary: Calculate the second moment of area enclosed by this curve on a the XY plane about the Y-axis, were the start and end points joined by a straight line segment, excluding the void regions specififed as boundaries.

member.returns: The signed second moment of area enclosed by this curve, as a double.

If true (default) collapsed segments will be removed.
If true (default) the attributes of this curve will be copied to the offset one.

member.name: M:Nucleus.Geometry.Curve.OffsetInwards(System.Double@,System.Boolean,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Offset this curve on the XY plane, automatically determining (where possible) the direction of offset which will result in the curve being offset within itself. Note that it will not be possible to accurately predict this for all curves.
member.param: The offset distance. Positive numbers will result in the offset curve being to the right-hand side, looking along the curve. Negative numbers to the left. This will be automatically inverted (in-place) if the curve is anticlockwise so that positive numbers entered will result in an offset inwards and negative numbers outwards.

member.name: T:Nucleus.Geometry.CylindricalCoordinateSystem
member.summary: Represents a cylindrical coordinate system defined by an origin, longitudinal axis and a polar axis lying in the reference plane, and positions are defined by radius, rotation around the longitudinal axis from the polar one and a distance from the reference plane, or r, theta and z respectively. Positive values of theta represent anticlockwise rotations around the longitudinal axis.

member.name: F:Nucleus.Geometry.CylindricalCoordinateSystem.Default
member.summary: The default cylindrical coordinate system. The origin is at the global origin. The longitudinal axis is set to the global z-axis The polar axis is set to the global x-axis.

member.summary: The unit vector defining the longitudinal axis

member.name: F:Nucleus.Geometry.CylindricalCoordinateSystem.A
member.summary: The unit vector defining the polar axis on the reference plane

The polar axis vector

member.name: T:Nucleus.Geometry.Plane
member.summary: Represents an infinite plane described in terms of an origin point and a local coordinate system, where X and Y axes lie on the plane and the Z axis is normal to it. The coordinate system of the plane is right-handed. Immutable geometric primitive.

member.summary: Get the curve parameter at the vertex at the specified index

member.name: M:Nucleus.Geometry.PolyCurve.PointAt(System.Int32,System.Double)
member.summary: Evaluate a point defined by a parameter within a specified span.
member.param: The index of the span. Valid range 0 to SegmentCount - 1
A normalised parameter defining a point along this span of this curve. Note that parameter-space is not necessarily uniform and does not equate to a normalised length. 0 = span start, 1 = span end.
member.returns: The vector coordinates describing a point on the curve span at the specified parameter, if the curve definition and parameter are valid. Else, null.
member.remarks: The base implementation treats the curve as being defined as a polyline, with straight lines between vertices.

member.name: M:Nucleus.Geometry.PolyCurve.CalculateEnclosedArea(Nucleus.Geometry.Vector@,Nucleus.Geometry.Plane)
member.summary: Calculate the area enclosed by this curve, were the start and end points to be joined by a straight line segment. A plane may optionally be specified, otherwise by default the projected area on the XY plane will be used.
member.param: Output. The centroid of the enclosed area, in local coordinates on the specified plane.
The plane to use to calculate the area. If not specified, the XY plane will be used.
member.returns: The signed area enclosed by this curve on the specified plane, as a double.

member.name: M:Nucleus.Geometry.PolyCurve.Add(Nucleus.Geometry.Curve)
member.summary: Add a new sub-curve to this PolyCurve. Note that to form a valid polycurve the new sub-curve *must* start at a point within tolerance of the end point of the last sub-curve.
member.param: The curve to add.

member.name: M:Nucleus.Geometry.PolyCurve.Add(Nucleus.Geometry.Curve,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Add a new sub-curve to this PolyCurve. Note that to form a valid polycurve the new sub-curve *must* start at a point within tolerance of the end point of the last sub-curve. If autoConnect is set to true, this condition will be checked for and a line segment automatically added to connect the curve ends if necessary.
member.param: The curve to add.
If true, a line segment will automatically be added between the end of the last curve and the start of the newly-added one to close any gap between them, if necessary.

member.name: M:Nucleus.Geometry.PolyCurve.AddLine(Nucleus.Geometry.Vector)
member.summary: Add a new line segment to the end of this polycurve. The line will run from the end of the last subcurve in this polycurve to the specified point. This polycurve must contain at least one subcurve already in order for the start point to be determined.
member.param: The end point of the new line segment.

member.name: M:Nucleus.Geometry.VertexCollection.ClockwiseTestSum
member.summary: Returns a sum value of (x1 - x0)(y1 + y0) for each vector between vertices in this collection, which can be used to test whether the vertices are overall stored in a clockwise or anti-clockwise direction. If the result is greater than 0, the collection is clockwise. If the result is less than 0, the collection is anticlockwise. If the result is 0, it is indeterminate. The final vector from the last vertex to the first one will also be included.

member.name: T:Nucleus.Geometry.Vector
member.summary: 3D Vector structure. Represents a position or direction in 3D space through X, Y and Z components. Immutable.
member.remarks: This type is currently implemented as a structure instead of a class for reasons of efficiency. This may be reviewed once benchmarking has been performed, however. As the size of this struct exceeds the recommended 16 bytes, it may work out that passing vectors around in function arguments etc. is inefficient.

member.name: M:Nucleus.Geometry.Vector.ManhattenDistanceTo(Nucleus.Geometry.Vector)
member.summary: Calculate the Manhatten distance from this position vector to another. The Manhatten distance is the is the sum of the absolute difference between each component of the two vectors - i.e. it is the distance you would have to travel from one point to the other if you could only move orthogonally along the global axes.
member.param: Another position vector.

member.name: M:Nucleus.Geometry.VectorExtensions.ClockwiseTestSum(System.Collections.Generic.IList{Nucleus.Geometry.Vector})
member.summary: Returns a sum value of (x1 - x0)(y1 + y0) for each vector between points in this collection, which can be used to test whether the points are overall stored in a clockwise or anti-clockwise direction. If the result is greater than 0, the collection is clockwise. If the result is less than 0, the collection is anticlockwise. If the result is 0, it is indeterminate. The final vector from the last vertex to the first one will also be included.

member.name: T:Nucleus.DDTree.DDTree`1
member.summary: The abstract base class for Divided-Dimension Trees. This data structure works a lot like a binary partition tree only instead of branching in two each time, each level of the D-D tree is subdivided into a number of evenly-sized partitions. This allows for much faster spatial indexing in cases where objects are reasonably evenly distributed throughout a particular region of space. To implement a tree to hold a particular type of object, this class should be extended and the abstract functions overridden to deal with that type.

member.name: F:Nucleus.DDTree.DDTree`1._RootNode
member.summary: The root node of the tree

member.name: P:Nucleus.DDTree.DDTree`1.MinCellSize
member.summary: The minimum allowable cell size

member.name: P:Nucleus.DDTree.DDTree`1.MaxLeafPopulation
member.summary: The requested maximum number of objects per leaf node. If newly added objects increase the object count beyond this, the node will automatically subdivide. Note that the MinCellSize limit may mean that some nodes will contain more than this number.

member.summary: Get the next token, parsed to a double. The position of the reader will then move along to the next token, such that repeated calls to Next___() will return each token in sequence.

member.summary: Get the next token, parsed to an integer. The position of the reader will then move along to the next token, such that repeated calls to Next___() will return each token in sequence.

member.name: M:Nucleus.IO.TokenReader.Next3AsVector
member.summary: Read the next three tokens and parse them as a Vector's X, Y and Z coordinates. The position of the reader will then move along to the next token after these, such that repeated calls to Next___() will return each token in sequence.

member.name: M:Nucleus.IO.TokenReader.Next6AsSixVector
member.summary: Read the next six tokens and parse them as a Six-vector's X, Y, Z, XX, YY and ZZ coordinates. The position of the reader will then move along to the next token after these, such that repeated calls to Next___() will return each token in sequence.

member.name: T:Nucleus.Maths.Interpolation

member.name: F:Nucleus.Maths.Interpolation.Linear
member.summary: Linear interpolation: t/d

member.name: F:Nucleus.Maths.Interpolation.Quadratic
member.summary: Quadratic interpolation: (t/d)^2

member.name: F:Nucleus.Maths.Interpolation.Cubic
member.summary: Cubic interpolation: (t/d)^3

member.name: F:Nucleus.Maths.Interpolation.SquareRoot
member.summary: Square root interpolation: (t/d)^0.5

member.name: F:Nucleus.Maths.Interpolation.CubeRoot
member.summary: Cube root interpolation: (t/d)^1/3

member.name: F:Nucleus.Maths.Interpolation.Exponential
member.summary: Exponential interpolation: (exp(a*(t/d))-1)*1/(exp(a)-1)

member.name: F:Nucleus.Maths.Interpolation.Elastic
member.summary: Pseudo-elastic interpolation: 1/(exp(a)-1)*cos(b*(t/d)*2*PI)*exp(a*(t/d))-1/(exp(a)-1)

member.name: F:Nucleus.Maths.Interpolation.Sin
member.summary: Sine interpolation: sin(a*(t/d)*2*PI)

member.name: F:Nucleus.Maths.Interpolation.Cos
member.summary: Cosine interpolation: cos(a*(t/d)*2*PI)

member.name: F:Nucleus.Maths.Interpolation.Step
member.summary: Step interpolation: jumps from one value to another at the mid-point

member.summary: The lateral and rotational directions in which this node is fixed for the purpose of structural and physics-based analysis. Represented by a set of six booleans, one each for the X, Y, Z, XX,YY and ZZ degrees of freedom. If true, the node is restrained in that direction, if false it is free to move.

member.name: T:Nucleus.Model.CrossSectionClass
member.summary: The classification of a profile cross-section, indicating the extent to which the resistance and rotation capacity of cross sections is limited by its local buckling resistance.

member.name: F:Nucleus.Model.CrossSectionClass.Indeterminate
member.summary: The cross-section type has not been or cannot be determined

member.name: F:Nucleus.Model.CrossSectionClass.One
member.summary: Class 1 cross-sections are those which can form a plastic hinge with the rotation capacity required from plastic analysis without reduction of the resistance.

member.name: F:Nucleus.Model.CrossSectionClass.Two
member.summary: Class 2 cross-sections are those that can develop their plastic moment resistance, but have limited rotation capacity because of local buckling.

member.name: F:Nucleus.Model.CrossSectionClass.Three
member.summary: Class 3 cross-sections are those in which the stress in the extreme compression fibre of the steel (or aluminium) member assuming an elastic distribution of stresses can reach the yield strength, but local buckling is liable to prevent development of the plastic moment resistance.

member.name: F:Nucleus.Model.CrossSectionClass.Four
member.summary: Class 4 cross-sections are those in which local buckling will occur before the attainment of yield stress in one or more parts of the cross-section.

member.name: T:Nucleus.Model.LinearElement
member.summary: A linear element is one defined in terms of a set-out curve and a section that is swept along the curve to define the 3D solid geometry. Used to represent objects where one dimension is greater than the others and the overall geometry can be represented as an extrusion along a curve, such as Beams, Columns, Walls, Pipes, etc.

member.name: P:Nucleus.Model.LinearElement.StartNode
member.summary: The node (if any) that the start of this element is connected to. This is a shortcut property to get or set the node attached to the start of this element's geometry curve. Note that Nucleus element geometry is not dependent on nodes and so this property may have a null value.

member.name: P:Nucleus.Model.LinearElement.EndNode
member.summary: The node (if any) that the end of this element is connected to. This is a shortcut property to get or set the node attached to the end of this element's geometry curve. Note that Nucleus element geometry is not dependent on nodes and so this property may have a null value.

member.name: T:Nucleus.Model.ModelObjectSet`2
member.summary: Abstract generic base class for parametrically defined 'sets' of objects which allow collections to be defined via a base collection and a set of logical filters which act upon that collection.

member.name: F:Nucleus.Model.ModelObjectSet`2._BaseCollection
member.summary: Private backing field for BaseCollection property

member.name: P:Nucleus.Model.ModelObjectSet`2.BaseCollection
member.summary: The base collection of items to be considered for inclusion in this set. Filters will be applied to this collection to determine the final collection of objects which constitute this set. If this and the SubSets property are null, but the Set has been added to a model, all objects of the relevant type within the model will be considered for inclusion.

member.name: T:Nucleus.Model.ModelObjectSet`6
member.summary: Abstract generic base class for parametrically defined 'sets' of objects which allow collections to be defined via a base collection and a set of logical filters which act upon that collection.

member.name: F:Nucleus.Model.ModelObjectSet`6._SubSets
member.summary: Private backing field for SubSets property

member.name: P:Nucleus.Model.ModelObjectSet`6.SubSets
member.summary: The base collection of other sets to be considered for inclusion in this set. FIlters will be applied to the expanded contents of these sets to determine the final collection of objects which constitute this set. If this and the BaseCollection property are null, but the set has been added to a model, all objects of the relevant type within the model will be considered for inclusion.

member.name: F:Nucleus.Model.ModelObjectSet`6._Filters
member.summary: Private backing field for Filters property

member.summary: Private backing field for Fixity property

member.name: P:Nucleus.Model.NodeSupport.Fixity
member.summary: The lateral and rotational directions in which this node is fixed for the purpose of structural and physics-based analysis. Represented by a set of six booleans, one each for the X, Y, Z, XX,YY and ZZ degrees of freedom. If true, the node is restrained in that direction, if false it is free to move.

member.name: F:Nucleus.Model.NodeSupport._Axes
member.summary: Private backing field for Axes property

member.name: P:Nucleus.Model.NodeSupport.Axes

member.name: F:Nucleus.Model.NodeSupport._Stiffness
member.summary: Private backing field for Stiffness property

member.name: P:Nucleus.Model.NodeSupport.Stiffness
member.summary: The stiffnesses in the translational and rotational degrees of freedom of this support. By default this stiffness is 0 in all directions. This property is only considered when the fixity in the relevent direction is set to false - otherwise the node is taken to be fully restrained in that axis and the stiffness is effectively infinite. Expressed in N/m.

member.name: P:Nucleus.Model.NodeSupport.IsFree
member.summary: Does this support not actually restrain the node in any way? i.e. are all fixity directions false and all stiffness components zero?

member.summary: Modify the orientation of this element so that the appropriate axis of the local coordinate system (Z for linear elements, X for panels) points as closely as possible towards the specified guide vector.

member.name: T:Nucleus.Model.Element`2
member.summary: Generic base class for elements - objects which represent physical model entities and which are defined by a set-out geometry which describes the overall abstract form of the element and by a volumetric property which determines how that design representation converts into a 3D solid object.

member.name: F:Nucleus.Model.Element`2._Geometry
member.summary: Private backing member variable for the Geometry property

member.name: P:Nucleus.Model.Element`2.Geometry
member.summary: The set-out geometry of the element. Describes the editable control geometry that primarily defines the overall geometry of this object. The set-out curve of 1D Elements, the surface of slabs, etc. The assigned object should not already be assigned to any other element. When setting, the previous geometry (if any) will have any attached nodes removed to prevent memory leaks. If you wish to set the geometry of this element but retain existing attached data such as vertex nodes, use the ReplaceGeometry function instead of directly setting this property.

member.name: M:Nucleus.Model.Element`2.ReplaceGeometry(`0,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Replace the set-out geometry of this element, automatically copying over any relevant data attached to the original geometry such as vertex nodes and cleaning up any residual data on the old geometry to prevent memory leaks.
member.param: If true, data will only be copied between vertices if the old and new vertex are within tolerance of one another. If false (default) data will be copied regardless.

member.name: F:Nucleus.Model.Element`2._DerivedGeometry
member.summary: Private backing field for the DerivedGeometry property

member.name: P:Nucleus.Model.Element`2.DerivedGeometry
member.summary: Storage for derived geometric objects attached to this element. These represent geometric forms that the element may be represented by or may attain under certain circumstances (such as structural deflection plots) but they do not form part of the idealised defining geometry of the element - for the set-out geometry of the element consult the Geometry property instead. NOTE: Currently Not Serialized - temporary data only

member.name: P:Nucleus.Model.Model.Everything
member.summary: Get a single flat collection which contains all sub-objects within this model, for easy iteration through the entire database in one go. This collection is compiled when called from the different sub-tables within the model - it is not stored and modifying this collection will not result in any changes being made to the model itself. Use the Elements, Nodes, Properties, Materials etc. properties instead to modify the model.

member.name: P:Nucleus.Model.Model.Create
member.summary: Create new objects in this model. Returns a ModelObjectCreator instance which provides factory functionality to create new objects within this model and to track their creation history. The functions accessed via this property will normally create new objects and add them to the model, but if the execution information matches that of a stored object that object will be updated and returned instead. This allows objects to be easily created and updated via parametric processes. Model objects may alternately be instantiated and added to the model manually, however this will not track their creation history.

member.name: P:Nucleus.Model.VertexReleases.Stiffness
member.summary: The stiffnesses in the translational and rotational degrees of freedom of this release. By default this stiffness is 0 in all directions. This property is only considered when the release in the relevent direction is set to true - otherwise the element is taken to be fully restrained in that axis and the stiffness is effectively infinite. Expressed in N/m.

member.summary: Obtain a measure of the apparent brightness of the colour, ranging between 0-1. The colour components are weighted differently when calculating 'brightness' in this way; Red is weighted by 0.3, green by 0.59 and blue by 0.11 - the brightness is the unitized combination of all three values.

member.summary: Register the specified object and, if it is a collection, any items contained within it to be watched for undoable operations. Raised CollectionChanged events and PropertyChanged events that use the PropertyChangedEventArgsExtended type for arguments will result in a new UndoState being automatically created. Any new items added to a watched collection will themselves be automatically watched.
